<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module5_mcq_q85')" data-correct-answer="D">
<strong style="display: block;">In the Fama-French-Carhart (FFC) model, what does the factor HML (High Minus Low) capture?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module5_mcq_q85" value="A"> A. The excess return of the market portfolio over the risk-free rate</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module5_mcq_q85" value="B"> B. The return difference between small-cap and large-cap firms</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module5_mcq_q85" value="C"> C. The persistence of returns based on past performance</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module5_mcq_q85" value="D"> D. The return difference between value (high book-to-market) and growth (low book-to-market) stocks</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module5_mcq_q85" value="E"> E. The impact of investor mood and attention on returns</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module5_mcq_q85" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
âœ… Correct: D. HML measures the premium that value stocks (high book-to-market) have historically earned over growth stocks (low book-to-market), one of the central anomalies motivating multifactor models.
